document: Software Evolution and Maintenance (Chapter 2) discusses the taxonomy of software maintenance, evolution, categories of concepts, and challenges of maintaining component‑based systems.

questions.question: Corrective maintenance is intended to fix failures that occur in a running system.
Adaptive maintenance seeks to modify the software to improve its performance regardless of changes in the data or processing environment.
Perfective maintenance is also known as reengineering, which involves restructuring code for better readability and maintainability.
Preventive maintenance prevents problems from occurring by modifying the software product before any defect appears.
Activity‑based classification divides maintenance activities into three categories: corrections, enhancements, and prevention.
Evidence‑based classification groups maintenance types based on changes to hardware components used by the system.
Investigation activity is one of the four maintenance types defined in Chapter 2.
The abbreviation SPE stands for Specified, Problem, Evolving.
P‑type programs are specified with a formal specification of all functional and non‑functional properties before they are written.
The acceptance of an E‑type program is based only on its runtime performance metrics.
Lehman's first law states that software size grows linearly over time.
Declining quality means that users experience improved performance as the system ages.
Software process execution aging manifests as degradation in performance or transient failures of a continuously running system.
Code decay includes improved readability of changed code as one of its characteristics.
A commercial off‑the‑shelf (COTS) component is defined as an independent unit with contractually specified interfaces and explicit context dependencies only.
When integrating COTS components, the primary code written by integrators is tailoring the source code of the components.
The openness of a component influences the maintainability of a component‑based system.
A change‑control board approves proposed changes after investigation and before implementation.
Level 1 support in a maintenance organization primarily develops patch releases for the system.
Preventive maintenance is intended to reduce entropy by improving architecture and design over time.
